data.title: grep support
data.body:
I want something akin to `M-x grep` in emacs. The native find functionality isn't doing it for me.

I want to pass grep things like `--include` and the whole slimy cohort, then step through the results as in `build-tools-cpp`.

I can't find this functionality in atom or in any packages. Am I just missing it?

data.title: Atom keeps adding desktop shortcut
data.body:
Atom keeps recreating its desktop shortcut unexpectedly. I'm guessing it's something involved in the automatic update process, since it doesn't happen all the time. Creating a desktop shortcut on initial installation makes sense, but doing it every time a background update occurs does not.

I'm using Atom 0.176.0 on Windows 8.1 x64.

data.title: Feature Request: Magic Package Object
data.body:
Let me start off by describing my use case. I'm writing a package where the version number is prominately displayed in the main view. Something like "Welcome to this awsome Atom Package v-X.Y.Z". In order to find the version number of the installed package, I have to write out this really long ugly line of code:

``` coffeescript
versionNum = atom.packages.getLoadedPackage('my-package').metadata.version
```

and it got me thinking that it would be really nice to have a free variable that refers to _this_ package, much like the node free variable `module` refers to _this_ module. So instead of that long, ugly monster I could instead write:

``` coffeescript
versionNum = package.metadata.version
```

which would mean _my_ package's version number or even better:

``` coffeescript
versionNum = package.version
```

Please note that this is not a vital request, and I can live without it. I simply think it would be convenient and much more elegant. Also note that I have no idea where to even begin implementing this, or if it's even possible to begin with. But I can't be the only one using my own package's metadata progmatically, so if it is possible, hopefully there's someone out there who could make it happen and make life on us package developers just that much easier! :smile:

data.title: Cursor disappears after switching tags (Awesome WM)
data.body:
Cursor disappears after switching between tags in [Awesome WM](http://awesome.naquadah.org/).

Steps to reproduce:
1. Atom is focused on tag `1`, cursor visible
2. Switch to tag `2`, <kbd>modkey+2</kbd>
3. Switch back to tag `1`, <kbd>modkey+1</kbd>
4. Atom is focused on tag `1`, cursor invisible

---

Atom `0.176.0` on  GNU Operating system

data.title: Make rpm install package a little more flexible
data.body:
:penguin: Took a couple things that were hard coded to be absolute paths and made them relative. This makes it much easier to install Atom in a non-standard location on Linux and have it just work.

However, with default settings on the build scripts, everything still behaves the same as before these changes.

data.title: Settings->Packages page scroll is not remembered
data.body:
First time user, fresh install, but long time Sublime text 2/3 user (more than 2 years).
After i installed atom, i went to settings to check all the options, and one thing that really annoyed me was that after i click a package name (or the settings button for that package), to see its configs/properties, if i click at the top of the window "Packages" again, the list position is reset, so for example if i am at the middle of the list, i have to scroll again and find my position. 

Also another thing is that if i click (in the same menu) multiple times the "Settings' button, i can not see the "Packages" button at the top, so my only possibility is to go on the left panel and click "Packages" there (this again resets my scroll position)

data.title: atom.config.get '<some-color>' doesn't return an instance of Color if set in config.cson
data.body:
When I try to `get` a config value of a setting with the `color` type, and the setting is saved to `config.cson` (so not the default value), I don't get an instance of the `Color` class, but rather just the object/string that was in `config.cson`.

Versions:
Atom: `0.176.0`
OS: Linux Debian 8 (testing)

data.title: Fix broken npm package.json link in creating-a-package.md
data.body: Fixes #5304

data.title: Broken link in Atom documentation
data.body:
[docs/creating-a-package.md](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/9132859757c73b0c00f97b2a72db7feff9067c3c/docs/creating-a-package.md#packagejson) has a link to npmjs.org, but this link is 404 now. Perhaps one of the following two links can be used to replace this link:
- https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json 
- http://browsenpm.org/package.json

data.title: Only a suggestion
data.body: Would be great like Chrome and Firefox if we could to login with GitHub account and then sync all settings, themes, extensions...

data.title: Uncaught Error: EEXIST, file already exists '/Users/USERNAME/.atom/storage'
Find and Replace All in a project doesn't add the file changed icon in the sidebar until you view that file
data.body:
If you use Find and Replace All to make changes in files in the project which aren't currently open, the sidebar won't show that the file has changed until you click to open and view the file.

**What should happen** - The sidebar should show that the file has changed, or open all those files in the editor with the changes. Sublime does this and leaves them unsaved, forcing the User to Save All.

data.title: http://github.com -> https://github.com
data.body: Change http://github.com to https://github.com to avoid plaintext HTTP connections.

data.title: Transpile all .js files beginning with the "use 6to5"; pragma with 6to5.
data.body:
Transpile all .js files with 6to5.

In the spirit of supporting JavaScript development for Atom packages,
this adds default support for es.next transpilation support in the way
that Atom already has default support for CoffeeScript transpilation.
There are many new features in ES6+ that make JavaScript development
easier and more enjoyable, particularly in terms of support for async code.

For reference, this was a much faster way to iterate on this than running `./script/build`
each time:

```
cp /Users/mbolin/src/atom/static/index.js /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/index.js
coffee --output /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src --compile /Users/mbolin/src/atom/src/esnext.coffee
```

Run the following in the console to see how warm the cache was after startup:

```
global.require('../src/esnext/').getCacheHits()
global.require('../src/esnext/').getCacheMisses()
```

data.title: Atom on windows crashes a lot of it's attempting to do filesystem operations on a mounted network drive
data.body: Specifically, I'm editing files on an OSX samba share. When I do any file system operations in the tree view, the app crashes. Also sometimes it just crashes. But mostly it works!

data.title: Ability to set syntax via the command palette
data.body:
Sublime Text has the ability to set the syntax of your file using the command palette.  It has a command called "Set Syntax" that will switch the syntax of the currently opened document.

The Sublime Text web page has an example of it in action where the user types "sspy" to fuzzy find the command "Set Syntax: Python".

The only way to open the syntax menu in Atom seems to be clicking the current syntax in the bottom-right corner of the window.  There doesn't seem to be any keybind or command to open that window.

data.title: Windows: "Paul Betts" folder appears in Start Menu
data.body:
I'm on Windows 7. I updated Atom from 0.175.0 to 0.176.0 yesterday. Today, I noticed a new folder in my Start Menu Programs called "Paul Betts". The folder is empty. The creation time is just 13 seconds after the creation of the folder atom/app-0.176.0/resources and before the creation time of the rest of the files in atom/app-0.176.0.

This seems like a bug. In case it's relevant, I do remember closing Atom during the update process.
